title: 115_s1942
content: "Savanna's Act" is the short title of the Act. The purpose of the Act is to address findings related to a specific issue. Congress finds that on some reservations, Indian women are murdered at more than 10 times the national average. American Indians and Alaska Natives are 2.5 times more likely to experience violent crimes and at least 2 times more likely to experience rape or sexual assault crimes compared to other races. Over 4 in 5 American Indian and Alaska Native women and men have experienced violence in their lifetime. According to the Centers for Disease Control. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, homicide is a significant cause of death for American Indian and Alaska Native women in certain age groups. Investigations into missing and murdered Indian women are hindered by a lack of resources and interagency cooperation, as well as inadequate laws. The jurisdictional complexities in Indian country negatively impact public safety in these communities. The Act aims to clarify responsibilities and enhance coordination among law enforcement agencies to address cases of missing and murdered Indians, empowering Tribal governments with necessary resources. The Act aims to increase data collection and information sharing among Federal, State, and Tribal officials regarding missing and murdered Indian men and women. The Act aims to increase data collection and information sharing among Federal, State, and Tribal officials regarding missing and murdered Indian men and women. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms related to databases, Indians, Indian country, and Indian land. The Act defines key terms related to databases, Indians, Indian country, and Indian land, including definitions for Indian lands, Indian tribe, and law enforcement agency. SEC. 4. IMPROVING TRIBAL ACCESS TO DATABASES. The Attorney General will provide training to law enforcement on recording Tribal enrollment information of victims in Federal databases. A formal consultation with Indian Tribes, in cooperation with the Secretary of the Interior, will be completed to enhance Tribal data relevance and database access. The Attorney General will enhance safety for Indian women by improving access to crime information databases and implementing a dissemination strategy for the National Missing and Unidentified Persons System. Additionally, specific outreach will be conducted with Indian Tribes to facilitate public entry of information into the system. Publicly enter information on missing persons, including family members and acquaintances, through the National Missing and Unidentified Persons System or other portals. SEC. 5. GUIDELINES FOR RESPONDING TO CASES OF MISSING AND MURDERED INDIANS. The Attorney General shall direct United States attorneys to develop guidelines for responding to cases of missing and murdered Indians, including inter-jurisdictional cooperation and best practices for conducting searches on Indian land. The curr_chunk provides guidance on conducting searches for missing persons on Indian land, collecting data on missing persons and unidentified remains, culturally appropriate identification of human remains, responsibility for inputting information into databases, improving law enforcement response rates to cases of missing and murdered Indians. The curr_chunk outlines guidelines for ensuring access to culturally appropriate victim services for missing and murdered Indians. United States attorneys are required to consult with Indian Tribes and various federal partners to develop these guidelines. Compliance with the guidelines must occur within 60 days after the next sexual violence response annual consultation in each region. The United States attorneys must modify sexual violence response guidelines to incorporate developed guidelines and each federal law enforcement agency must also modify their policies. The Attorney General will determine if Tribal, State, and local law enforcement agencies have incorporated the guidelines into their protocols annually. For fiscal years 2019 through 2023, the Attorney General will prioritize grant applications from Tribal, State, or local law enforcement agencies that have incorporated guidelines. The Attorney General must disclose compliance determinations annually. The Attorney General will prioritize grant applications from law enforcement agencies that have incorporated guidelines. The Attorney General must disclose compliance determinations annually and update records accordingly. Training and technical assistance will be provided through the National Indian Country Training Initiative. The Attorney General will provide training and technical assistance to Indian Tribes and law enforcement agencies on implementing guidelines for responding to cases of missing and murdered Indians, as well as using the National Missing and Unidentified Persons System. Annual reporting requirements are outlined in Section 6. The Attorney General must provide annual reports to Congress on missing and murdered Indians in the United States, including statistics on age, gender, tribal affiliation, open and closed cases per state, and other relevant information. The Attorney General's annual reports to Congress on missing and murdered Indians in the United States include statistics on age, gender, tribal affiliation, open and closed cases per state, and other relevant information while maintaining victim privacy. The Attorney General's annual reports on missing and murdered Indians include statistics on age, gender, tribal affiliation, open and closed cases per state, and recommendations for improving data collection. Starting from the first fiscal year after the enactment of this Act, the Attorney General will request Tribal, State, and local law enforcement agencies to submit relevant information for the annual report. The Attorney General will disclose annually the names of law enforcement agencies that did not submit requested information. Preference will be given to grant applications aiding in implementing guidelines for Tribal, State, or local law enforcement agencies. Beginning in the first calendar year after the enactment of this Act, the Federal Bureau of Investigation will include gender in its annual statistics on missing and unidentified persons published on its public website. The Senate passed S. 1942 on December 6, 2018, directing the Attorney General to review and develop protocols to address missing and murdered Indigenous peoples.
